text: This is Guillermo Martínez.

At just 24 years old, 
he’s already

making the world
a better place.

In 2017, he bought his
first 3D printer for $172,

and before the year was up,
he was printing and fitting
prosthetic arms and hands
for people all over Kenya.

And the best part? He’s giving 
them out free of charge.

Narrator: Martínez is
an engineer by trade.

He currently prints various
prosthetics he calls Trésdesis.

They're designed 
and fit for people

who are missing part or
all of their arm.

Narrator: The limbs are
based on a high-tension
string mechanism.

Anytime you rotate your
wrist, elbow, or shoulder,
it tightens the strings.

This makes the 
prosthetics more useful

than if they were just
a solid piece of plastic

because it means that
they can move more like

can grasp and grip objects.
In fact, each prosthetic can hold
up to 10 kilograms of weight.

Narrator: An estimated 
30 million people

in low-income countries
need prosthetics,
and it can be difficult to get one
because they're so expensive.
Aid organizations like

the International Committee
of the Red Cross can help,

but producing and
fitting a prosthetic
can cost around $1,000.
That's eight months of income
for the average worker in Kenya.
That's where 3D printers

and people like Martínez
are making a difference.

Since some of the first
3D-printed prosthetics
were made around 2008,

from around $10,000 
to just $700.

And this drop in cost
has led to an explosion
in the market and technology.

The end result is that
people like Martínez
can print prosthetics

and then give them 
to people in need

who might not otherwise
be able to afford them.

To date, Martínez has
delivered over 50 prosthetics

to people in developing 
nations worldwide

including Kenya, El Salvador,
Chad, Morocco, and Tanzania

as well as other
countries like Spain.

He's also launched 
a new project online,

which produces and
delivers these prosthetics
to people who request them,
and he's also training children
to use 3D-printing technology
so that someday they'll be able
to print prosthetics themselves.
